SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: William Albert Cadman
Present Address: 323-7th Ave., Saskatoon
Pioneer Address: Macario, Sask.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1904

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER RECOLLECTIONS AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many hours were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How often did you usually visit neighbors' homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors' homes? How often did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go—morning, noon, or afternoon?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

9. Did you ever have "sewing" where groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "reasons" were for, and how often they occurred.

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what drives or dances in homes? How often were these held?

11. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Did any country dances take place?

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.? Did these ever hold parties in the villages or towns?
1. In the first ten years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors' homes? Did you make a special arrangement?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days of the week?

4. Were you often invited to other people's homes? Or was most visiting done without an invitation? If so, what was the reason?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "please join us" used, or was there another expression?)

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

9. Did you ever have these "open house" gatherings together to put up a billiards, make quilts, or other such activity?

10. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "guesse" were for, and how often they occurred.

11. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, "play drives" or dances in homes? Describe.

12. Were there more frequent in later years? Give dates. Why?

13. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.? Where and how often?
6. Tell what was made of the school house for community games, box socials, etc., if you have not heard that there was no school house. Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built after the R.R. came to [town]? How large was it? Who built it? How large was it? Who built it? How large was it? Who built it?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were tables and small children provided for?

What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the house, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some residents did not approve of card playing.
6. Tell what use was made of the schoolhouse for community dances, box socials, etc., other activities. (Include also the school children's parties, birthday parties, etc.)

7. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

8. What material was it made of? (Describe.)

9. When was your first community hall built? (Describe.)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the house, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some residents did not approve of card playing.
12. What attempts at "formality" or "rampant" do you remember in small towns, such as places like this when calling, calling back, visiting, treated seriously in public, etc.? 

13. Was the obverse known in your community? 
Describe what you remember about obverses, telling how common they were.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments already mentioned that were popular at parties or other social gatherings at that time so you can whom some obverses in visiting or social life because noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? 
Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers Local in your community? 
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

17. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district? 
When was it organized? 
Approximately how many women belonged to it? 
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at Forming, or "working" do you remember in small towns, such as those mentioned above? Tell what was done, who started it, when, etc.

13. Are the churches known in your community? Describe what you remember about churches, telling how common they were and any influences connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular at parties and similar entertainments (not suitable for visiting or social life because of lewdness).

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the Civic organization of any kind that you remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? If so, describe its organization, and what stage led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to it?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

They organized a trading disbursement and sold local grown foods after their harvest and many other things at cost.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

(There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

24. What games did boys play in summer (e.g., marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

25. What games did girls play in summer (e.g., birdhouses, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outdoors - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Family," "whist," "parcheesi" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, popcorn or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it? A Community Picnic at Mrs. John Faup's home on Broadfield in 1918. Picnic in March.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, game organization, etc.? This was for the Community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? The first I can remember.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? There were boat rides on the slough, and races and jumping and other sports.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? It started at 4:00 and afternoon affair.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
That games were played indoors in winter - such as "Happy Family," "Mushrooms or others," checkers or other? 
Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PASTimes AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first platoon that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it? A Community Platoon at Mrs. John Fergusson's.

27. Was it for the entire community or for a smaller group, such as a school district? (Young school) young families only?

28. Was it the first platoon held in the community? If so, when?

29. What were the arrangements at the platoon you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics; school or Sunday School picnics; family picnics; etc.; tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (boys, women only).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1908

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving dates of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played in competitions in larger centers, etc.

In Muncie, there was a good football team in these early years.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, skating, etc.). When was a second rink built, and what was it used for?

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

A large indoor rink was built in 1928 and used for skating, hockey and curling.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1908

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

A large indoor rink was built in 1928 and used for skating, hockey and curling.
